name: Trains: Rising Sun
description:
Trains returns with all-new cards and strategies for you to build the best rail system in Japan. Trains: Rising Sun not only features all new cards, it includes three entirely new boards. Two of the boards are designed specifically for two-player games, while the Nagoya map is for 3 to 4 players. This standalone game can mix easily with the original Trains game for even greater replay possibilities!

Trains: Rising Sun also introduces Route Bonus Cards, allowing you to score additional points for being the first to connect specific stations. Route Bonus Cards are included for the original Trains game as well!

Finally, Trains: Rising Sun includes the Trains: Nagoya Map expansion that was first produced only by the designer for use with the original OKAZU Brand production of Trains. (This item is not linked to in the information box for database reasons.)

name: The Confederate Rebellion
description:
"The Confederate Rebellion" is a solitaire wargame (with optional two player rules) on the American Civil War. The game is based on ACW Solitaire but contains updated and new rules, clarifications, new artwork, and new scenarios.

In the solitaire game, the player controls the Union forces and the Rebellion is controlled by an AI. The game takes place over an unspecified number of turns. Play continues until either the victory or defeat conditions are met.

Each turn follows this sequence of play:
1. Union Build Phase: The Union player builds units (Armies, Gunboats, General, Fleet, Forts) during this phase. In addition, a Union General may be sacked. 
2. Union Move Phase: Union units may move Regions this phase. 
3. Union Combat Phase: Any combat resulting from Union movement is resolved. 
4. Rebel Build Phase: The Rebels may build units as permitted by certain circumstances. 
5. Rebel Move Phase: Rebel Generals may move as permitted by die roll. 
6. Rebel Combat Phase. Any combat resulting from Rebel movement is resolved.

The goal of the game is to prevent the Rebellion from having resources available to build and maintain their army. Once this achieved, the Union player wins. If the Rebellion ever controls four Union areas or Washington DC, the Union player loses.

name: Stalingrad Solitaire: Death Knell of the German 6th Army 1942
description:
Stalingrad Solitaire: Death Knell of the German 6th Army 1942 is a game focusing on the German assault on Stalingrad and focuses on the time period of September 2, 1942 - September 4, 1942. While primarily a solitaire game, the special edition also contains optional two player rules.

The player controls the German forces and must battle the Russian Army to control as many regions of Stalingrad as possible. The game is played by deploying German units on a map of Stalingrad. The AI (or an optional second player) controls the Russian forces through movement, placement, and attack rules.

The game plays out over 15 turns (although shorter scenarios are provided). Each turn, the player will place Russian forces in the Ferry areas on the Volga River (these units are placed upside down and are not revealed until attacked). The German player will then raise troops and move units to instigate combat. The AI rules then dictate how the Russian units will counter attack and conduct movement.

Victory is determined by controlling all the Urban areas of Stalingrad at the end of a turn. The game can end early if the player achieves the victory conditions before the end of turn 15. If the player doesn't control the Urban areas by the end of the game, it is a loss.

name: Wer reist mit nach Afrika? Ein Unterhaltungs und Belehrungsspiel
description: Players start in Germany. They follow routes through Africa, to numbered circles, and end back on Germany. The board is a map of Europe and Africa, with plants and trees along the bottom. Players roll and move to travel around the board, and then do what the field is saying.

name: MLTG: Maritopian Life The Game
description:
Maritopian Life brings you the first game of its kind; a collectible Trading Card Cannabis Game.

Be a grower. Build your grow room. Create obstacles for your opponents.
Protect your room from other growers. Be the first to score 420 points for the win. For Adults only.

Each deck must have at least 40 cards. Points are accumulated by harvesting plants after the number of turns on a strain card.

name: ESSEN
description:
In ESSEN, players are exhibitors who are trying to sell their games at a large board game fair in the well-known western German city of Essen. By placing their sellers, creating buzz, and managing their promotional efforts correctly, they can turn a profit and get board game geeks excited about their games. Each player board is themed as a certain type of game publisher (eurogames, ameritrash, war games, RPGs) with the reverse side showing other possibilities (abstract, children's games, party games, LARP).

ESSEN is a game for 2-4 players, and by combining two copies of the game up to 8 players can play at the same time.

name: Yin-Yang
description:
Yin-Yang is a brief abstrat game for two players, each player takes both of the white and the black stones for playing. They take turns placing stones on the 5x5 game board, for the purpose of making a square by four stones in the same color. 
In the game, each player belongs to Yin or Yang side. So does the square been made on the board. The player who’s Yin-Yang is the same as the square wins the game.

On which the Yin-Yang of a square depends:
White stone is Yang; 
Black stone is Yin;
Odd number of lines of gribs the square covered is Yang;
Even number of lines of gribs the square covered is Yin;

Combining Yin-Yang of the stones with the size of the square just as  multiplication rules of plus and minus, the result is the Yin-Yang of the square:
White stone x Odd number = Yang
White stone x Even number = Yin
Black stone x Odd number = Yin
Black stone x Even number =Yang

name: Yoink!
description:
In Yoink! players must close their eyes or wear sleep shades and quickly pass tactile cards. Players are not allowed to use their eyes so all players, blind or sighted, are on an equal playing field.

Players must feel the cards to determine when they have cards with all the same or different attributes. In the center of the table there are totems (we use dice) enough for all the players except one. When a player has a set that is all the same(or all different) number of shape, type of shape and background fill they will reach for the totems at the center of the table.

Once the first player has their trio they declare 'Yoink!' and the remaining players scramble to get the remaining totems. Players who don't get a totem are eliminated and play continues.

name: Countdown: 5 Minutes to Self-Destruction
description:
Countdown: 5 Minutes to Self-Destruction is a real-time cooperative dice-rolling game about escaping a space research station being invaded by alien forms trying to get their hands on human advanced technology. The self-destruction mechanism has been triggered and players only have 5 minutes to kill the aliens blocking their way to the emergency exit hatch.

Players are dealt six face-down alien cards showing the hit pattern to complete in order to kill the alien. The hit patterns consist in 4 or 5 dice in various colors and values. When the game starts, a timer is triggered, all players flip the first card in their deck, and then simultaneously roll dice as fast as they can, in order to complete the hit patterns lying in front of them. Once a pattern is complete, the player flips the next card and starts rolling dice again to complete the new pattern revealed. Dice can (and in some cases must) be passed between players to complete their patterns.

If all players manage to complete all the patterns they were dealt at the beginning of the game, they reach the escape pod safely and leave the space station unharmed. However, if the timer reaches zero before all patterns are completes, the space station explodes with aliens and humans aboard, and everyone lose.

name: Ascension: Realms Unraveled
description:
Ascension: Realms Unraveled is a deck-building game in which players acquire cards from a central pool, then place those cards in their discard pile to be shuffled into their deck for later use; creatures also show up in that shared card pool, and players can combat them to earn victory points (VPs) and possibly other benefits, such as the ability to remove less useful cards from their deck or to banish cards from the pool that others might find useful. The game ends once all the available VPs have been claimed or the shared deck of cards runs out.

Ascension: Realms Unraveled, part of the Ascension deck-building game series, is both a standalone game for 2-4 players (with solitaire rules included, too) and an expansion that can be combined with any other Ascension game to support up to six players.

While cards in previous Ascension games have always belonged to one of four factions, Ascension: Realms Unraveled introduces multi-faction heroes, and these heroes combine with the new "Multi-Unite" game mechanism to deliver huge rewards to those who play multiple heroes from the same faction.

Ascension: Realms Unraveled also features the "Transform" mechanism that debuted Ascension: Darkness Unleashed, with players being able to convert their cards into new, more powerful versions as the game progresses.

name: MazeScrolls
description:
MazeScrolls are a series of maze puzzles games in the form of scrolls. They are a new kind of game genre: the pen and paper maze puzzle dice games for multiple players.

There are 8 different MazeScroll designs and each one uses different graphics and offers different game-play. The eight MazeScrolls are the following:

- Galaxy Far, Faar, Faaar Away
- Perimeter Perplexity
- De Stijl Mile
- Daedalus Treasure
- Lovers Duel
- Daedalus Palace
- Crossing
- Skritches, Skretches and Skrutches

MazeScrolls are a game of meandering journey that can be played by a single player or multiple players. Players can race from one end to the opposite end or they can start at opposite ends and attempt to find each other. Players can also "duel" by first collecting power points so that when they meet-up the one with the most power wins.

Players play the MazeScroll games using a pen, pencil or colored pencils. When the game is done, the finished MazeScroll becomes a piece of artwork that is also a record of their play.

name: Mechadrome: Heavy Metal Combat
description:
Hundreds of years from now, the greatest sport the galaxy has ever known will explode on your screens as everyone watches their favorite teams of giant Mechs beating each other to scrap. Mechadrome is a "Mech Combat Gladiator Arena Skirmish Game" set in the far future where man and alien races have come together, forming teams that do battle in arenas set in abandoned, war-torn cities and industrial zones.

The rules are simple, fast & fun and you may build your Mechs with a wide variety of devastating weapons, or use our own pre-made teams like the Terran Titans or Team Bushido. The game features a variety of scenarios such as Capture the Flag or No Mech's Land, the objective will always be different, so no game will ever be the same.

Mechadrome Mech models are available in 28mm scale, and made from traditional resin.

name: MYOB
description:
MYOB is a Rogue-like, Dungeon Crawler Card Game playable with a standard deck of cards and 5 six-sided Dice.

Single or Multiplayer, MYOB brings the RPG experience in a way that tributes Classic games like Solitaire and Yahtzee.

Players explore a dungeon by drawing cards and placing them on the field to build monsters, and defeating monsters by rolling dice against their Bounty to collect them and their Loot. Loot comprises of Weapon, Armour, and Magic cards. Weapon and Armour cards increase attack and defense, and Magic cards are used to negate combat damage. Defeat both BOSS monsters to win and collect the highest Bounty.

name: Pocket Odyssey
description:
Pocket Odyssey is a micro dungeon crawling game inspired by traditional table top RPG games. It takes place in the Dungeonfell, also known as the buried plane, with all but one player acting as a group of adventurers on a quest. The quest is created by the last player, known as the storyteller, who must create a set of challenges based off of quest cards randomly drawn at the start of the game.

The game concept can be described as putting the spirit of a traditional pen and paper RPG into a micro table top game. Players pick a character background card (ex:  Ogre Slayer, Swindler King, etc.) and add special power cards to them (ex: Fireball, Backstab, etc.) they then draw a Flaw card which gives them a unique attribute (ex: chronic liar, Impatient, etc.) and a personal goal card (in secret) which they must complete in addition to the main quest to win the game (ex:  Outsmart an enemy, Betray a party member, etc.).

During combat the game is played on modular map cards with heroes and monsters acting in sequence; the storyteller controls all the monsters. Heroes obtain loot cards at the end of combat in addition to leveling their characters stats. To win the game, each player must complete the main quest developed by the storyteller (through the use of the quest cards) as well as their own personal quest cards (which are kept hidden until completed).

name: Bird Whiz
description: Bird Whiz is a card-run-making game, published in South Africa in the 1990s (likely 1993 or 1997). It uses colours or you can match them up by type of bird. Once you get a run you put it down, but to keep it in play, you have to answer a question related to the birds in the run. You could skip this part for younger players. With the questions, it makes it an educational game. It is easy to teach and learn. There are also joker cards counting as any card. You score points for the amount of runs you have down. You also score negative points for the cards in your hand once the game ends. The worst card to end up with in your hand is a joker, losing you 50 points. The winner is the one with the most points.

name: Leben in Kassel
description:
Published about the German City of Kassel.

By playing the players get to know a little bit about the city and its shops.

During each player's turn they roll a six-sided dice to move along a game-board depicting a map of Hannover. At certain spaces players can acquire cards of the shops or they can go sightseeing by following the instructions on the back of the card. Sometimes there is only information written, sometimes you have to pay an amount of money or at other times you may earn some cash.

The game ends when the last player reaches the finish space with his playing piece. The winner is the person who has acquired the most sightseeing and/or shop cards.

name: Monopoly: Erzgebirge Edition
description:
A monopoly (from Greek monos μÏŒνος (alone or single) + polein πωλεá¿–ν (to sell)) exists when a specific person or enterprise is the only supplier of a particular commodity.

Monopoly is a roll-and-move game where players move around the game board buying or trading properties, developing their properties with houses and hotels. When opponents land on players owned property, the owning player collects rent from the landing player. Owning sets of properties increases the rent paid to the player who owns them, by the player who lands on the square. The ultimate goal is to have the most money and drive opponents into bankruptcy.

The classic Monopoly with constructions and other elements from the Erzgebirge, an area in the south of Saxony.

name: Superbohaterowie
description:
Superbohaterowie is a Polish reimplementation of a game Eleminis. The main difference is that the Polish version supports the game from 2 to 5 players, while Eleminis is playable up to 8 players. There is also a smaller variety of action cards.

Moreover the theme is completely new. Superbohaterowie in Polish language means Superheroes.

Your goal in this game is to collect one of each of five superheroes in your city on the table. Players each have five slots available to them, and each slot can hold one card. On a turn, you draw a card from the deck then either play it in a row (if it's a superhero card) or use it (if it's an action).

Each superhero outranks two other superheros, similar to rock/paper/scissors/Spock/lizard. You can play a superhero card you draw in any empty space or replace a weaker superhero with the new one; you can play in your row or an opponent's. A star superhero is wild and can represent any superhero you need; a giant spider card can replace any element and can be displaced only by a star superhero or an action card.

The actions let you discard cards in play, move cards, swap them. There are no cards which let you to lose your turn or reverse the turn order (which are in the Eleminis). Play continues until someone collects one superhero of each type in his city.

finish the circuit with less penalties than others
1. build an obstacle course upon a table cloth

earning penalties for each try (-1), for each damaged obstacle (-2),...

likely published mid. 1950's

name: Kennst Du Sie? ... die Daten der deutschen Geschichte
description:
Objective:
get as many bonus (bright) chips as possible; learn more about history of the German nation and become familiar with the ideology of Nazi Germany
 - acting by turns -
Game master draws a card and ask a player answering the question;
correct? Get a bright chip - Wrong? Get a dark chip. 
Game ends after each player has collected 10 chips. Winner is the one with most bright chips.
Note:
Questions are indoctrinated by Nazi ideology.

name: Dragon Valley
description: Dragon Valley is an engaging game for the whole family for players age 6 and up. The goal of the game is to return the dragon younglings to their valley before the nasty wizard gets back to his tower and catches them playing fireball near his home. To help the baby dragons, two players each take a wand and use their magic to transport them back to the Dragon Valley.

name: War of 1812 Battle Collection
description:
The War of 1812 battle collection is similar to the French and Indian War Battle Collection.

War of 1812 contains 12 separate battles with die cut counters terrain chart, rules and scenarios booklet.

This game pack may also be used as a scenario guide for miniature war gaming.

name: Symetra
description:
Symetra is a hexagonal-card, glass bead strategy game where players  battle for the opportunity to join Symetra, an ascended being who travels worlds, in battling a high tech evil on her home planet of Orbworld. To prove their worth the challengers must show their skill in wielding Symetra's reality-shaping interfaces that give the user access to the different elements, emotions and energies of the cosmos at a quantum level.

The challengers must actualize their potential energy, represented by their unique colour of glass beads, by fusing, combining and charging cards in the matrix. Once cards are energized in the matrix players can use their unique actions to shape their victory. The player with the most actual energy at the end of the game wins.

Symetra has many different play modes including short and long games, teams, draft, tournament, solitaire and oracle.

Symetra includes 60 unique hexagon-shaped cards, 300 glass beads (6 different coloured sets of 50 beads each) and a detailed rulebook.

name: MADNESS
description:
The world has been infected with the Madness Virus which has begun turning the population into blood-thirsty zombies. Help find the antidote formula and save the world before it's too late!

Madness is a fast-paced card game for 2 or 4 players ages 9 and up. There are no turns in the game and so players must think and play quickly in order to win. Match your ingredient cards to the ever-changing MADNESS formula before your opponent matches theirs - But be careful, if you select an incorrect formula you lose!

name: ESSEN The Game: SPIEL'13
description:
ESSEN the Game is a strategy game where each player is a visitor at the International Game Fair of Essen.

With your wishlist, face the crowd and make your way to the stands of your favorite publishers. However, beware that games availability is limited. To achieve your goals, you have to manage your budget and encumbering. The number of games that you carry will reduce your moves in the fair. You will need to come back to the parking lot to store your purchases in your car before getting back to the fair in search of that special game.

ESSEN The Game is the opportunity to live or relive a crazy day in the Kingdom of Games!

name: Destruction of Force Z
description:
Destruction of Force Z is a tactical level, solitaire simulation of the short air/naval campaign off the coast of Malaya in late 1941 which saw the destruction of two Royal Navy capital ships, HMS Prince of Wales and HMS Repulse by Japanese bombers. The player takes the British side, and the game system plays the Japanese side.

The object of the game is for the British to disrupt Japanese invasions taking place, while not losing his ships. You as the player are presented with a difficult situation. Pearl Harbor has just been attacked; the entire Malayan peninsula is under threat of invasion. There are not many offensive options open to you and your ships, but doing something to take the war to the enemy is preferable to meekly doing nothing at all. Perhaps you can disrupt invasion sites? Intercept enemy warships? Whatever you decide, it will be an uphill battle for the British. In the actual campaign, Force Z sailed out of Singapore into the South China Sea in the early evening of December 8. Admiral Phillips, onboard the Prince of Wales, ordered strict radio silence. If the two British capital ships were able to reach the Gulf of Siam undetected, they might be able to wreak havoc among enemy warships, transports, and invasion sites. If they were found, they risked the wrath of land-based Japanese bombers located in Indo-China. But danger from this eventuality was judged to be minimal, even though the RAF had warned the Admiral that they could not guarantee protection of the ships from the air.

The stage is set, the campaign is about to begin. Can you pull off a British victory, and avoid the destruction of Force Z?

The game includes:

     an illustrated 12-page digest-sized rule booklet that includes all rules and tables necessary for play, 
     a small map and 
     set of 59 counters (which must be printed and separated before play, depending on version), 
     Reference Card, and 
     optional ship counters for a game variant, originally published in Panzerschreck #16 (2014). 


—description from the publisher for 2018 edition

name: The Crossroads
description:
The Crossroads is a classic play of Chinese operas. Ren Tanghui was ordered to protect the banished general Jiao Zan in secret. He stayed overnight at Liu Lihua’s inn. Late at night, they confronted each other in a sudden darkness and dangerous hand-to-hand combat.

The Crossroads is a brief paper-and-pencil game for two players. In a room of 3x3 grids, players take actions concurrently each round and record them on sheets, then make an announcement required to settle their acts.

The basic acts include:

Move: Move to an adjacent grid.

Research: Get the last entry and left directions and round numbers in your position in 8 rounds from the opponent. You have to take a Move act next round.

Attack: Attack the opponent in your position, if he ends round here and doesn’t take an attack action, you win. You have to take a Move act next round.

Pursuit: Move and attack the opponent. You have to stay in the new grid without any actions next round.(3 uses only for each player)

For each Move round a player may also take a Challenge, declare his current position and earn points. In a series of consecutive challenges, it’s 1 point for the first challenge, 2 points for the second, 4 points for the third, 8 points for the fourth and later ones. After 20 rounds without a successful attack, the player has the most points win the game.

name: Dino-Land
description:
It's a game you can wear!  Both tee-shirt and board game, where you try to get your dinosaur to the end before the other players.

(You must provide the die and player markers.)

name: A Straight Road
description:
A Straight Road is a car racing game set in a post-apocalyptic future. Inspired by the countless movies of that genre, you race down a long (it almost seems endless) straight, ever-changing highway, trying to kill off all your competitors, run over the most valuable pedestrians, reach the gas station first or a variety of other goals, depending on the scenario you pick. Sometimes you will be on your own, sometimes you will be part of a gang.

There are many cars, drivers, passengers and equipment available that can be combined freely to build the wheeled killing machine of your dreams. However, the scenario only grants you a certain amount of credit to do so, each car only has a limited load capacity and, of course, the better the gear and the driver, the more expensive.

Game play is simple and fast. Each turn you change your speed, drive and take an action. You attack your opponents with your mounted guns, molotovs, rockets and more, lay mines or leave oil puddles for the guys behind you to slip in, ram other cars and wracks out of your way. Your ability to do stuff changes, depending on how fast you are going and what you are trying to do. However, only in very few cases you will need to calculate anything, most of that is taken care of by the layout of the game material; You just check your current value and roll a six-sided die. While you will want to stay on the road, circumstances often will force you to drive on the shoulder, where going gets rougher and steering more interesting…

Most of the game is free to print and play, you will, however, need small models to represent your cars; Micromachines work well, or any other model of roughly that size. If you deem Thunder Road too simplistic and Car Wars too fiddly, this might be a game for you.

name: Historia
description:
In Historia, the players guide their civilization through 12,000 years of human history, from the first sparks up to the development of Singularity. Civilizations discover new technology and expand over the planet; they trade with more developed neighbors to import new technologies or exploit the land to have more power for future actions. Civilizations develop their military and wage wars with each other. They build wonders to make their civilization stand above others and to eventually attract tourists and newcomers to their land to follow their leaders and use their national advisors.

Historia is a civilization game for 1-6 players that takes 25 minutes per player. A set of action cards is available to the players to guide their civilization, and used actions form a discard queue from which they are taken back into a player's hand during the game. Wars and raids are carried out in a non-disruptive way. When modern times have been reached the game ends and the player with the most VPs wins.

A solo Historia variant with A.I. bots is also available.

Flavor text:
History is made by strong leaders and wise advisors, by conquests and discoveries, by wars and trade and amazing wonders. Historia is made by you.

name: Ronda
description:
Objective: Gain as much money as possible
- acting by turns -
Players determine a wager; active player throws 2 dice:
On a board - numbered from 3 - 11 (7 in the centre) you have to pay money if the appropiate space/number is empty - collect money - if not. If you throw a 7 you have to pay anyway.
Throwing a 2 you collect all the money without '7', a '12' let you take all. 
note: published before WWII

name: Replicate
description:
After scanning many galaxies, many stars, and many planets, you have arrived and found the perfect host to take over humanity. However, you are not the only one. Your probe must compete against others to release virus and take over your host.

Players take on the role of an alien species, controlling a probe that moves around a human's body and releases virus. But, the virus must overcome the body's natural defenses as well as competing for dominance with the other viruses.

Probes arrive in any of the six origin spaces and begin to take over the host's body. As the body's defenses break down, taking over becomes easier until it is taken over completely. The virus that takes over enough body parts, wins the game.

Players must manage a hand of cards, a board position with its virion pieces, and a probe that requires actions to use. Cards synergize well with each other when used in the right configuration and can allow a player to maximize advantages. Also, cards have a different effect when used against the body and when used against other viruses.

name: Ringwurfspiel "Treff sicher!"
description:
Simple indoor ring toss game
- acting by turns -

Players choose a colour and throw plastic rings, hoping to catch one fn the targets and score some points.

The one who scores the most points after a pre-determined time limit runs out, wins.

Note: 
Published before WWII

name: Destination: Neptune
description:
Destination: Neptune shows an optimistic vision of commercial space exploration in the next century. Players control an organization with the resources and intent to explore, develop, and colonize the worlds beyond Earth. Organizations that practice careful planning and resource management, with a healthy dose of technology research will succeed. Destination: Neptune moves through four generations of space exploration. Players earn Victory Points by building large commercial outposts and colonies, as well as from fame and outright purchases. After four generations, the player with the most Victory Points wins the game.

This is a card driven game in which most Cards have an action that happens immediately, and another action for all of the players (including the player who played the card). Players can also sell cards in exchange for currency. When you sell a card, it goes to an Opportunity Track and is placed to the side of the board. If the Opportunity Track already has as many cards as players, the rightmost card is discarded. You may not change the order of the cards in the Opportunity Track. Players can play cards from the Opportunity Track as if they were in their hands.

Players must use the cards to gain currency and fuel in order to launch space missions to establish bases, factories and colonies on various locations within our solar system. Careful hand and resource management is key to winning the game. In addition, players also need to research certain technologies in order to build on most locations. Technologies are researched through card play and paying currency. The cards are separated into 4 piles which are separate generations. At the end of each generation, each player scores points for the various structures they've built. The game ends when all generation piles have been exhausted.

7.description: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet

8.description: Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups

9.description: Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

name: Intrigue in the Royal Court
description:
Each player represents a royal family that is attempting to influence the King or the Queen of an Ancient Kingdom in order to gain the royal favor that will make you become the next most powerfull family in the land.

In order to achieve the goal the players will have 10 (Ten) Archetypes they will use to surround the Royal Consort of their color with as much influence as possible.

The player who uses with cunning the resources at his/her disposal will be the winner.


SETUP

Each player will place his/her 10 tiles with the ACTIVE (This is the side with the banner) side up in his/her Activation Zone (Area close to the player where all the archetypes will enter play or return from play)

Place the king and the queen in the middle ground between the players in the same row with 2 spaces between them.

The game will be played in an imaginary grid with each space the size of one tile.

GAMEPLAY

Flip a coin, roll a die, find your method of convenience to choose a first player.

The game will be played in turns one player at a time. On your turn you must do the following actions:

1) PLAY A TILE from your Activation Area.

The first tile played by each player WILL NOT ACTIVATE ITS ABILITY. So it is very important you choose well which of your archetypes wont be used in the beginning of the game.

A tile played must always be adjacent to another tile (even diagonally) So you cannot place a tile anywhere in the imaginary grid.

A tile played always enters the game on the side it was in the Activation Area. So if the tile played was ACTIVE it stays with the side of the banner up and if the tile was INACTIVE it stays with the side that has a token drawn.

Consider INACTIVE tiles as protected from abilities when they are in PLAY since abilities cannot target INACTIVE tiles. It´s a very good strategy to keep this in mind because an opponent won´t be able to affect one of your INACTIVE tiles.

2) ACTIVE its ability (if possible)

Tiles that have been affected by an ability are turned to the INACTIVE SIDE (the one with the token on it). Same happens with the King and Queen.

Abilities cannot affect tiles that are in play with the INACTIVE SIDE up. This means that once a tile has been turned to the INACTIVE SIDE it´s safe on the board. It can be moved as usual by its owner but will not altered by an opponent.


3) MOVE ONE OF YOUR TILES IN PLAY ONE SPACE (diagonally or perpendicularly)

Notice that the joker has a special ability that allows you to move ONE MORE TIME after you placed it. This is a very strategical ability that can make big difference when you are trying to reposition a high influence tile on your turn or when you want to remove an opponent tile as well. Under no circumstance a tile can end up or move over another tile in the table.

When you move a tile it must always end adjacent to another tile. So you cannot move it on empty space unless it ended there due to the movement of the other tiles.


END GAME & WINNING CONDITIONS

The game will end when one of this two conditions happen:

1) One player starts his/her turn with his target consort surrounded by his own tiles  (perpendicularly).

The victory is total. The more you play the less this condition is going to happen.

2) The players have played all of their tiles.

Once the players have played all of their tiles comes the scoring. For this step only the tiles that surround PERSPERNDICULARLY (up, down and sides) each royal consort will count. Add all the influence numbers in the tiles, PLUS all the tokens if there are INACTIVE tiles among them (each one is worth 1 point) MINUS the total influence on the tiles your opponent has surrounding your royal consort. Compare this numbers... the player with the most influence WINS the game. In case of a tie... you are both too smart to outwit each other :)


COMPONENTS

20 double sided tiles
1 king
1 queen

22.description: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet

23.description: Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups

24.description: Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

name: Xhaos Theory: The Miniature Game
description:
Your Minions serve you without question. You are their Gawd. Their souls feed you in your quest toward the power to realize XHAOS THEORY. As you carefully wager their souls in bloody battles against other Gawds you risk losing those precious souls. A Gawd without worship ceases to exist.
Command and guide your minions carefully or all hope is lost.

Xhaos Theory is for those that have always asked “What if?” Young and old, experienced or not. Play with a massive miniature collection, or just a handful of models or toys.

Xhaos Theory allows you to create virtually any miniature unit you want, from any time frame, and fantasy or Sci-Fi book you have ever read and take that force up against another player that has created their own force. That force could be a one miniature force of a giant city eating lizard, or a squad of super heroes, or perhaps a legion of undead! Scenarios, settings, number of models? That's all up to you!

Xhaos Theory is a scalable miniature wargame allowing players total control over size and setting. You can play a full out large scale battle, or a small skirmish with Xhaos Theory. Many battles have been fought with 7 miniatures on one side, and 20+ on the other.

Xhaos Theory is a turn based miniature war game simplified for younger gamers also for quick play. Complete customization of your own army and campaign system to advance your army.

name: Shifty Partners
description:
Shifty Partners is a partnership trick-taking standard deck playing card game, with randomly-selected trumps. Partnerships change with each hand, and scoring is by individual. Trumps change with each hand, determined by a d6 die-roll.

The object of the game is to have the most points at the end of the game. The game ends after each player has dealt one hand. During the game, each player will be partnered with every other player. Partnership designations shift after each hand. A unique feature is that the dealer is always a partner with the player on his right.

A partial deck is used, with the number of cards determined by the number of players. Five cards are dealt to each player, with one being face-up. Only four tricks are played in each hand.

Each trick captured counts 1 point, and each Queen and Deuce counts 1 point. Each member of a partnership scores the total points caught by the entire partnership.

47.description: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet

48.description: Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups

49.description: Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

name: Der Weg zum Igelhaus
description:
Objective:
be the first reaching space 90 - simple 'Roll&Move'-game.
Each player moves forward according die roll; ending on a marked/larger space follow instructions.

note:
cute drawings on a 23" x 15.3" map,
likely published 1950's

name: Typo 2D
description:
In Typo 2D, you try to play your cards next to cards already on table so that you can say words that start with the letter combinations in the rows or columns. In this game's predecessor, Typo from 2004, players placed letter cards in four separate rows; in Typo 2D, players can build "words" in two directions, crossing words as in crossword puzzles. The first player to play all of his cards wins.

In each game round, all players choose one of their hand cards, then reveal them simultaneously. In alphabetical order, players place their card adjacent to a card on the table to create or extend a row or column of letters. You must then say a word that starts with the letters in this row or column. If you extend a row and a column at the same time, you must say a word for the row and a word for the column. Once five or more rows/columns consist of at least two connected cards, you may place a letter only if you extend the length of a row or column to three cards or more.

If you cannot place a letter card because you can't create a word, then you must remove all cards from the longest row or column and add half of these cards to your hand. (Set the other cards aside as a penalty pile.) If you still can't place a letter in order to create a word, you must remove another word, etc.

If you place a letter card and connect separate areas of the grid — which were separated due to someone needing to remove a word — then you discard one of your penalty cards.

Typo 2D includes icons on some cards that can be used for variants, such as a card that can replace another card or a card you must place behind an empty spot and "fill in" the empty spot by saying a word.

name: 7 Card Stud
description:
This is a Poker variant with a novel twist. Each player gets two cards and then tries to 'shoot' a ball into the spinner (rather like a Roulette wheel). You have four balls to shoot but you can stop if you think you have a card that improves your hand. Of course, there is a lot of scope for bluffing.

Game contains:
Board
Spinner
Playing Cards
Poker Chips
16 Plastic balls in four colours
Rules

name: New York
description:
Objective: Using the detailed street map of New York each player is given five companies to be established in the city as close to the centre as possible.

With the help of dice and counters, each players chooses where to place, turn or remove company tiles.
Once a company is established on the map, the corresponding four 'places worth seeing' are revealed, so familiarizing players with the sights of the city.

Contents: 80 cards, 8 counters, 3 dice, rules and city information.

name: Super Sunday Football
description: American Football game that uses bits of film to show the outcome of chosen plays. Each player uses a playbook, one for defense and one for the offence. Plays are chosen and the apt piece of film shows the outcome.

name: Knuckle Busters
description:
Action boxing game similar to Rock 'Em Sock 'Em Robots. Each player controls a boxer. The boxers face each other and start throwing punches. A clean punch to the nose will knock down that boxer. Play as long as you like, the one with the most knock-downs is the winner.

Included is a 45 rpm record of ring-side sound effects, which you can play in the background to build up the atmosphere.

name: Ring Toss
description:
Indoor target game. Each player in turn will take the three plastic rings and try to throw them over the post. Most successes wins.

It is advertised as being two games in one because you can choose the post to be in a fixed base or you can choose the slightly harder game where the post is fitted into a base that rocks around as you hit it.

name: Carrera
description:
This is a car racing game. The first player to complete a prior agreed upon number of laps wins the game. Each turn, each player moves the spinner two times. The first spin determines the the number of spaces he can move his car. The second spin results in an event, that can influence his movement or allow him to draw a card. The players start with 6 cards. The cards can be played to gain advantages for ones own movements or hinder the opponents movements. The colored segments on the race track symbolize speed limits, which can be exceeded by playing double-, triple- and risk cards.

This game was most likely published in the 1960s.

name: Sunda
description:
The goal of the game ist to get points by enclosing opponent playing pieces. The players can set their pieces (with their faces down) on any free space on the game board. When all pieces are set, the players beginn to move their pieces one space per turn. If a piece is enclosed, so that it can't move, its face is revealed. It's eliminated from the game and the encloser gets the indicated number of points, but only if a black inscripted piece is caught on a space with a black center or a white inscripted one on a space with a white center. If this is not the case, the enclosed piece is put on any other free space of it's players choice. When a 6-eyed piece is eliminated, it's player too is eliminated from the game.

This game was published in the 1930s or 1940s.

name: Am Knobelbrett
description: The players set their playing pieces face down on the spaces of their color on the game board. Only the spaces with the number 10 are left free. When all pieces are set, the faces are revealed. Now the players have to move their pieces to get them on the spaces of the same number. Spaces of other colors can't be moved on. Neutral spaces can be used to block the opponents. The first player to get all his pieces on the right spaces wins the game.

name: Das lustige Affenspiel
description:
Objective: be the first reaching space 70 (catching Tom, an orang-outan)
 - smple 'Roll&Move' game - 
acting by turns
Tom (an orang-outan, kept as prisoner/domestic animal in a palace) has escaped. Rolling two dice (with special symbols) 5 pawns (players) have to catch the break-away; depending on dice combinations pawns/orang outan have to be moved; ending on marked spaces follow instructions.

notes:
likely published before WWI;
cute pewter pawns, funky story behind

name: Hounds of War
description:
Hounds of War Mk. II is a update to the original standardized skirmishing miniatures rules system which allows the players (with maximum flexibility during the CREATION phase) to be able to take ANY 25-30mm figures, assign them the game values the players WANT, and be able to bring them into play. With Hounds of War Mk. II you will be able to pit World War II Nazi Storm Troopers against your favorite Goblin Hoards, or even Star Wars© Storm Troopers!

This is a stand-alone set of rules, so no other rules are necessary for play. In addition,  you WILL need your own miniatures, a LOT of 10-sided dice (d10), marking chits, 3D terrain, rulers marked in inches, and your imagination to play this game.

Instead of being a "you-go-I-go" turn sequence, an initiative deck is used  and cards assigned to individual units to determine when units perform actions are performed in a turn. This creates a fast paced game in which players are constantly active.

Hounds of War Mk. II is the culmination of many post convention evaluations, fan suggestions, and clarifications. Inside you will find many clarified and expanded rules, as well as prebuilt armies, a campaign system suggestion, a victory point system, counter sheets, and much more. We thank all of you who have taken an active part in the growth of this system.

name: Jungs
description:
Objective: Collect as many bonus points as possible by crossing a 11 x 11 board (+ start/target positions) like Halma by
1. capturing other meeples 2. fast finishing 
 - acting by turns -

Players (2 or 4) move their meeples (vertical/horizontal/diagonal) out of starting position upon a 11 x 11 grid board. The board is divided into 4 areas, pictured with Skat-cards; starting from such a place you may move or jump trying to come closer to your finish positions; if you jump over opponent's meeple(s) you will capture them - but this isn't allowed if your starting position has a lower or equal value (according Skat). You may jump in all directions ('chain-jump') starting from a Jack-(=Jungs)space. Transition spaces between the 4 areas have additional restrictions/advantages. The earlier you finish the higher the bonus points. Game ends after last player reaches target positions.

Note:
Likely published during 1930's

name: Marquette-opoly
description:
Own it all as a high-flying trader in the fast-paced world of real estate. Tour the city for the hottest properties: sites, stations and utilities are all up for grabs. Invest in houses and hotels, then watch the rent come pouring in. Make deals with other players and look out for bargains at auction—there are many ways to get what you want. And for really speedy dealers, use the speed die for a quick and intense game of Marquette-opoly. So get on Go and trade your way to success.

Players move around the gameboard buying or trading properties, developing their properties with houses and hotels, and collecting rent from their opponents, the ultimate goal being to drive them into bankruptcy.  The winner is the remaining player left after all the others have gone bankrupt.

name: Corps Command: Dawn's Early Light – Red Hammer
description:
Now you command Soviet and NATO forces during the first battles of the Third World War.  Seven scenarios give you the opportunity to explore the desperate fighting in the Eisenbach Gap and Gerzenburg.  Dawn's Early Light: Red Hammer is the 2nd expanded edition of Dawn's Early Light and now includes the High Noon at Gerzenberg expansion from Line of Fire magazine #10. Dawn's Early Light Red Hammer is set in a hypothetical 1985 as World War 3 starts.  The game uses variable initiative, support element chit pulls, and a novel combat resolution mechanic to create a game modeling the lethality of the modern battlefield with a minimum of rules overhead.

Dawn's Early Light Red Hammer has been refined, corrected, and polished.  This edition has updated game manual, counters, player aid card and map.  The game map is now printed on a heavy paper stock in vibrant color and also includes a newly designed full-color box.  Players can control forces of America, Canada, West Germany and the Soviet Union.

Dawn's Early Light Red Hammer is easy to learn and play in an evening, so get ready to play.

22.description: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet

23.description: Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups

24.description: Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

name: GETSOME
description:
Operation World Party Gaming introduces GETSOME, GETSOME: Bad Decisions, and GETSOME: Ladies night, which are a series of naughty games for normal people.

GETSOME is a 2-4 'player' non-collectible card game, expandable up to 5-6 players with purchase of the expansion, Bad Decisions, and the deck can be enlarged through purchase of the first booster, Ladies Night. The goal is simple: earn yourself 10 Bed Notches while avoiding the consequences of your actions such as lost turns, Clingy Exes, STDs, and babies. The dialogue is both horrible and hilarious. Play is quick as everyone has the ability to play cards on another person's turn. A player will have seven cards in their hand and can GETSOME, become PREGGOS, gain a Status Effect, heal a Status Effect, or block a player from a GETSOME or PREGGOS encounter. Don't forget to call in your Wingman when the time is right.

The heart of the game is the story telling, where you'll create the details of your deeds and how you overcame difficult challenges presented by your so-called friends in pursuit of your next conquest. Your evening will be filled with buddies, belly laughs, and blushing cheeks of the newly acquainted.

The heart of the replayability is in the multifunction design of many of the cards to perform different tasks depending on your needs. There are an unlimited number of ways for rounds to play out. There's an amazing breadth of crazy things you'll hear yourself say over the course of the night, and a card for just about every occasion. Once you GETSOME, you're definitely going to want to GETSOME again.

name: Royaumes Africains
description:
A print'n play, pit and peebles inspired African themed game. During the medieval times, kingdoms and empires rise and fall in the African continent.

The object of the game is simple, it uses a mancala/oware/awele style mechanic.

As a player, take control of one of the four kingdoms, rise, expand, and collect resources before falling.

You will do so using a "pit and pebbles" gaming mechanic, sowing your cubes and harvesting with the last cube you sow.

You will also use cubes from new comers (Europeans, Chinese, Persians, Arabs...) as Africa become a land of conquest. 
You can sow and harvest player cubes with these cubes, but you can't harvest new comers' cubes.

So new comers will slowly gain control of the land as players use them, and players' kingdoms will fall.

At the end of the game, when there are no more players cubes, the winner is the player who has harvested the most cubes.

The game is for 2-4 players, from 6 y.o. The board is language independent, rules are in French, soon in English.

name: "GOAL"
description:
Objective: score most goals (450 points or more) during a 2 x 6 matches lasting game
 - acting by turns - 
2 or 4 players (in this case you need two sets/games with 4 different colours) are dealt 5 cards each (from their own 32 cards deck); trying to score most points in a trick-taking procedure you earn bonus points regarding the values of the cards (within their won tricks); special card combinations (center-forward & goal & Joker) give additional points. After each trick you must refill your hand.

notes: likely published mid/end 1930's due to Joker card 'Sindelar': Team captain of the Austrian Wunderteam - died Jan. 1939 under mysterious circumstances

name: Collectors Battlefield Wargaming System: D-Day – Battle of Carentan
description:
This is the first module of the Collector's Battlefield Wargaming System, a 'turn key' quick play set of rules with a full line of 28mm prepainted figures and vehicle.

CB: Carentan is a skirmish level miniatures wargame- that is, it represents combat at its most basic level of fighting: man to man.

CB:Carentan puts the player in the role of an infantry squad or platoon leader.  Firefights break out in 'mad minutes', followed by lulls where the player exercises leadership by rallying troops, bringing in reserves, and maneuvering his troops to set up for the next firefight.  Firefights center on the machine gun- placement of your MG42's and .30cals are crucial to glorious success or ignominious defeat!

Scale: 
1 figure = 1 soldier or vehicle
1 inch = 2 yards
1 turn = approximately 30 seconds
Combat Lull = 2 to 10 minutes.

Keeping track of units stats is made easy with quick reference cards included with every pack, detailing the capabilities of every squad, leader, heavy weapon and vehicle.  Squad level games are fast and furious, taking about 60 minutes to an hour and half.

name: Blumenzüchter
description:
Card game in which each player is a gardener who tries to get the best variety of flowers to grow in his garden.

There are flower cards and accessory cards, such as seeds, sunshine, water etc. Different kinds of flowers need different combinations of accessories and yield different point values.

The active player can draw cards, trade cards with open cards on the table, plant flowers and trade with the other players. The first player to plant ten points worth of flowers is the winner.

name: Turnier der Magier
description:
The forces of light and dark are running a tournament, with the winner ruling the earth for the next 100 years.

The game consists of cards showing magicians, spells, items and missions. Each player has a magician card with a special ability, and a mission card with another special activity. The active player can play cards with spells or items and use the abilities of his/her magician/mission cards. Other players can interfere with counterspells or special items. The goal is to gain three tokens, either individually (in a 2 or 3 player game) or as a team (in a 4 player game). The first player or team who gets the 3 tokens is the winner.

name: Monster Schreck
description:
The players are monsters and have to escape from the monster hunters. This is achieved by elimination: Every monster which gathers 7 or more hunter points is out of the game. Last monster standing is the winner.
Each player has a monster card and draws two action cards into his/her hands, then three hunter cards which are placed openly in front of him/her. Now each player can play action cards on two of the hunters and the monster card can attack the third one. Some action cards can take hunters out of the game while others can redirect them to other players (there is no defense against this). When all actions are resolved, the player with most hunter points has to keep the highest hunter card. When after a few rounds the number of hunter points a player has gathered exceeds 7, that player is out. The others continue untili only one monster is left.

name: Tactico!
description:
The game is played on a board with 16 numbered chips face down in three rows. The objective is to force your opponent to remove the last chip on the board. Players take turns removing up to 4 chips from any one row until only one chip is left. The player who removes the last chip scores the value on that chip. The first player to accumulate 30 or more point loses the game.

From the game box: Fast-paced family game is easy to play, tricky to win! Payers must count, strategize & think ahead!

name: Aztec Conquest
description:
The game is played on a board 10 squares by 9. Each player has 9 pieces which being placed side by side in two lines along one diagonal. The objective is to be the first player to move their 9 pieces into a 3 by 3 square in their corner of the game board.

From the game box: Slide carefully along the ground to the sacred Aztec temple ... Keep and eye on your enemy, overcome obstacles, and make sure all the members of your tribe reach the safety of the temple.

1. Assemble the Aztec warriors in diagonal formation along the center of the board according to tribal colors.
2. Slide a warrior along a row or column until he encounters a boundary or another warrior.
3. Plan the best route, slide the warriors forward and help them enter the sacred temple.
4. Be the first player to slide his/her entire tribe of nine Aztec warriors into the temple ... and WIN!

name: Alpaca Pakapaka
description:
Translated intro from the game manual:

An alpaca contest will be held. Breeders from across the country will compete to see who has the most beautiful alpaca. Scoring is determined by fashion sense and length of neck. To be victorious, please grow a beautiful alpaca! Let's grow a more beautiful opponent than our opponent! Negotiate with other players to collect accessories.

12.description: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet

13.description: Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups

14.description: Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

name: Rola In The Magic Forest
description:
YOU are an apprentice witch. You can procure magic from a variety of forest resources. You can create magic called "mug", and use it to carry out the extraction of "Mana" - the energy of nature. Who can hold the most excellent performance?! Please be careful so as not to get in the way of resource procurement earnestly. It is a card game that anyone can play easily!

- From the Magic Forest and Black Cat Rola

This card game uses trick taking mechanics. The suit color of the card winning each trick becomes the trump suit of the next trick. Cards earned become magical resources and can be combined to score bonus points.

name: Cat 10
description:
Cat 10 is a cute cat card game with easy rules in which you try to create the perfect cat hand! During the game, players reveal numbered cat cards and tally their sum, trying to get as close to 10 as possible. When your score equals seven or higher, you have a choice to make:


    You can change your goal to shoot for a target of 20 instead of 10 and keep revealing cat cards.
    You can score for the cards currently face up before you.
    You can discard the most recently revealed card to roll the dice and try to steal another player's score while simultaneously risking yours.

7.description: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet

8.description: Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups

9.description: Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

name: Squarit
description:
Squarit is a played on a board containing 16 squares each surrounded by four spaces for tiles, with each pair of adjacent squares sharing one tile space. Each tile space has a specific tile that can be placed on it. The squares are numbered from 4-64 by fours. The edges of the board are also numbered, from 1-4.

The game can be played in two ways. In the aptly-named "Game of Chance" two to five players take turns drawing a tile and placing it on its designated space. The player placing the fourth tile around a square scores the value of the square multiplied by the value of the edge of the board corresponding to the played tile.

The "Game of Skill" is for two players. The scoring rule is the same, but here each player starts with half the blocks and can choose which one to play, generally speaking. If three sides of a block have been played this forces the fourth side to be played as soon as possible, and if that is the third tile for another square it forces that fourth tile immediately, etc.

The designer patented the game some years before publishing it.

Note that the board shown in the patent is not exactly the same as the published version, as the rules state the squares in each quarter of the board sum to 136.

name: Game of Defense: Pacific
description:
Game of Defense: Pacific is a light wargame. It is for two sides (U.S. and "Asiatic"), each of whom has five ships each of three types (battleships, cruisers, and submarines). The ships are deployed on a map of the Pacific with a grid divided into red and white squares.

On a turn a player moves one piece (or possibly more than one, as the rules are a bit unclear). Battleships and cruisers can move several squares on a turn but are restricted to squares of a particular color. Submarines only move one square a turn but can use either color. Submarines capture enemy ships by landing on them, but the larger ships capture by jumping.

Each side starts the game by mining ten squares on their shores; when an enemy ship crosses such a square a card is drawn which may have a bad effect.

Each side has four objective cards which they randomly select one of at the start of the game, keeping it hidden from the opponent(s). The game is won by the side achieving its objective first.

The game can be played by more than two players by dividing one or both sides between players.

name: Minimal Space Combat
description:
Minimal Space Combat is a game of tactical space ship battle. The players design ships and then can battle to the death. It may be used with any scifi background as it has a very minimal theme. Players plot movement and then move simultaneously. Combat can occur at any time during movement when opposing ships are in range and in the weapons firing arc. The goal is simply to destroy the other player's ships.

Timothy Swenson describes the reasoning for designing this game as follows: 
"The premise behind this game is this: what is the simplest playable game possible to game tactical space combat. The game must make some reasonable attempt to come close to simulating space combat and not just the simplest possible game. The emphasis in this game is fast and easy. Playability is given more consideration than realism. There is no consideration for expansion of these rules, because then it would not be minimal. Use the game for those times when you want a quick and dirty space combat game or for introducing someone new to gaming."

In addition to the basic game Timothy also has minimal rules for a campaign game, a method for playing solo and a tutorial for introducing new players to space combat games.

17.description: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet

18.description: Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups

19.description: Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

name: SeaDogs
description:
SeaDogs is a fast paced family game for 2-6 players, ages 10 and up. Players take on the rolls of Pirate captains taking part in a competition to gather the most Gold and Treasure.  The Captain with the most Gold after all is said and done is the victor.

Sail into a port, and get gold by selling any cargo you have earned from your acts of piracy.  Pillage ports to gain cargo, but once a pirate pillages a port they must move to another Port to take any more actions.

There is no honor among Pirates, and it's every Captain for themselves on the high seas.  Players may attack each other and steal Cargo, Gold, or even Treasure that has been found on mysterious islands in the area.  Pirates who take plunder from other players get a Bounty on their heads that goes to the next Pirate to take them down a peg or two.

Sea Dogs has a whimsical style.  The world it takes place in is populated by animals.  The base game focuses on dogs, but who knows what other animals are out there.

SeaDogs is a quick playing game that is fun for kids and adults.  And it is designed to be kid friendly so everyone has a chance of winning, while still having enough depth that adults can play together and enjoy it as well.

name: Katsu Curry?! This is not the time for that!
description: It is currently an era of worldwide economic deflation. The politicians of your country seek to understand the common people. Players become the leaders of an opposition party who have taken it upon themselves to reestablish economic responsibility. Each player will bid to enforce a "fair and folksy" price of a variety of goods and services. Each time a player sets a price, they will earn honor points. The winner, and new political leader, is the player who earns the most points.

name: Monopoly: Landshut Edition
description:
A monopoly (from Greek monos μÏŒνος (alone or single) + polein πωλεá¿–ν (to sell)) exists when a specific person or enterprise is the only supplier of a particular commodity.

Monopoly is a roll-and-move game where players move around the game board buying or trading properties, developing their properties with houses and hotels. When opponents land on players owned property, the owning player collects rent from the landing player. Owning sets of properties increases the rent paid to the player who owns them, by the player who lands on the square. The ultimate goal is to have the most money and drive opponents into bankruptcy.

Monopoly set in Landshut, a German city in the Bavarian region.

name: Das Baden-Baden Spiel
description:
Commercial game, related to Monopoly, for the purpose of promoting the city of "Baden-Baden", in the Southwest of Germany.

The players move around a board, which consists of 40 squares. On most of the squares are parts of companies, which can be bought. The companies have values between 1000 and 8000. Three companies are combined by a color. Whenever a player lands on a win&loss-square, he must draw a card and the wins and losses of the business year are settled. According to the outcome the players gain money or have to pay money for their companies.
As soon as one player goes bankrupt, the game ends, all company cards are sold for their original price. Player with most money is the winner.
